greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of distinct solutions of 4/p = 1/a + 1/b + 1/c in positive integers satisfying 1<=a<=b<=c where p is the n-th prime.
comment: The Erdos-Straus conjecture is equivalent to the conjecture that a(n) > 0 for all n.
link: Jean-François Alcover, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
Christian Elsholtz, Terence Tao, Counting the number of solutions to the Erdos-Straus equation on unit fractions, Aug 2, 2015, arXiv:1107.1010 [math.NT], 2011-2015.
Elsholtz, C., Tao, T. Counting the number of solutions to the Erdos-Straus equation on unit fractions. Journal of the Australian Mathematical Society, 94(1), 50-105, 2013.
mathematica: a[n_] := a[n] = Module[{a, b, c, r}, r = Reduce[1 <= a <= b <= c && 4/Prime[n] == 1/a + 1/b + 1/c, {a, b, c}, Integers]; Which[Head[r] === Or, Length[r], Head[r] === And, 1, r === False, 0, True, Print["error: ", r]]];
Table[an = a[n]; Print["a(", n, ") = ", an]; an, {n, 1, 84}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Nov 22 2017 *)
program: (PARI) a(n)=my(t=4/prime(n), t1, s, c); for(a=1\t+1, 3\t, t1=t-1/a; for(b=1\t1+1, 2\t1, c=1/(t1-1/b); if(denominator(c)==1&&c>=b, s++))); s
xref: A292624 counts the solutions with multiplicity.
results.author: _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Jul 10 2011
